column2: Villefort rose, half ashamed of being surprised in such a paroxysm of grief.

column2: The terrible office he had held for twenty-five years had succeeded in making him more or less than man.

column2: His glance, at first wandering, fixed itself upon Morrel.

column2: Who are you, sir, he asked, "that forget that this is not the manner to enter a house stricken with death? Go, sir, go!" But Morrel remained motionless; he could not detach his eyes from that disordered bed, and the pale corpse of the young girl who was lying on it.
column3: Who are you, sir, he asked, "that forget that this is not the manner to enter a house stricken with death? Go, sir, go!" But Morrel remained motionless; he could not detach his eyes from that disordered bed, and the pale corpse of the young girl who was lying on it.

column2: Go!--do you hear? said Villefort, while d'Avrigny advanced to lead Morrel out.

column2: But in less than five minutes the staircase groaned beneath an extraordinary weight.

column2: See what they have done! cried Morrel, with one hand leaning on the back of the chair, and the other extended towards Valentine.

column2: See, my father, see!

column2: Villefort drew back and looked with astonishment on the young man, who, almost a stranger to him, called Noirtier his father.

column2: And the cry issued from his pores, if we may thus speak--a cry frightful in its silence. D'Avrigny rushed towards the old man and made him inhale a powerful restorative.

column2: One could have thought that he was undergoing the agonies preceding death.

column2: At length, happier than the young man, who sobbed without weeping, tears glistened in the eyes of Noirtier.

column2: Tell them--oh, tell them, that corpse belongs to me!"

column2: But you see that the angel whom you hoped for has left this earth--she has nothing more to do with the adoration of men.
column3: But you see that the angel whom you hoped for has left this earth-she has nothing more to do with the adoration of men.

column2: Take a last farewell, sir, of her sad remains; take the hand you expected to possess once more within your own, and then separate yourself from her forever.
column3: Take a last farewell, sir, of her sad remains; take the hand you expected to possess once more within your own, and then separate yourself from her forever.

column2: Valentine now requires only the ministrations of the priest."

column2: I tell you, sir, that two persons exist in you; the father has mourned sufficiently, now let the procureur fulfil his office.

column2: The eyes of Noirtier glistened, and d'Avrigny approached.

column2: Gentlemen, said Morrel, reading all that passed through the minds of the witnesses to the scene, "I know what I am saying, and you know as well as I do what I am about to say--Valentine has been assassinated!" Villefort hung his head, d'Avrigny approached nearer, and Noirtier said "Yes" with his eyes.

column2: Mr. Procureur," said Morrel with increasing vehemence, "no mercy is allowed; I denounce the crime; it is your place to seek the assassin." The young man's implacable eyes interrogated Villefort, who, on his side, glanced from Noirtier to d'Avrigny.

column2: Sir, said Villefort, striving to struggle against this triple force and his own emotion,--"sir, you are deceived; no one commits crimes here.

column2: I am stricken by fate.
column3: I am stricken by fate.

column2: And I say that murders are committed here, said Morrel, whose voice, though lower in tone, lost none of its terrible distinctness: "I tell you that this is the fourth victim within the last four months.
column3: And I say that murders are committed here, said Morrel, whose voice, though lower in tone, lost none of its terrible distinctness: "I tell you that this is the fourth victim within the last four months.

column2: I tell you that the dose has been double, the poison changed, and that this time it has succeeded.

column2: Noirtier wishes to speak."

column2: Alas, alas, sir, have pity on me!

column2: Oh, said Villefort, inexpressibly delighted to think that the inquiries were to be made by him alone,--"oh, be satisfied, I can understand my father." D'Avrigny took the young man's arm, and led him out of the room.

column2: At the end of a quarter of an hour a faltering footstep was heard, and Villefort appeared at the door of the apartment where d'Avrigny and Morrel had been staying, one absorbed in meditation, the other in grief.

column2: You can come, he said, and led them back to Noirtier. Morrel looked attentively on Villefort.

column2: Gentlemen, he said in a hoarse voice, "give me your word of honor that this horrible secret shall forever remain buried amongst ourselves!" The two men drew back.

column2: But, said Morrel, "the culprit--the murderer--the assassin."

column2: Do not alarm yourself, sir; justice will be done, said Villefort.

column2: My father has revealed the culprit's name; my father thirsts for revenge as much as you do, yet even he conjures you as I do to keep this secret. column2: I am going, sir; and I do not hesitate to say that no prayers will be more fervent than mine. D'Avrigny took the priest's hand, and without meeting Villefort, who was engaged in his study, they reached Valentine's room, which on the following night was to be occupied by the undertakers.
